subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Norisuke / Ron H.
msgSnippet: Ron, If you find any close matches in the book, or there is a similar kinko example- send me an image. I ll decide whether to track down and buy the book. This

Ron,

If you find any close matches in the book, or there is
a similar kinko example- send me an image. I'll decide
whether to track down and buy the book. This suba not
being signed, I doubt few other than a very confident
judge would give it *definitely* to Norisuke. But I
hope you find a dead ringer of a match for me.

A good number of people have told me they are skipping
San Fran this year for a variety of reasons. I am too,
due to business.

If you make it to Tampa in 2007, feel free to drive
down and fish off our dock. Snook is tasty. Right up
their with nice scottish rainbow trout.

Curran



--- Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

> Hi Curran - 
> 
> Sorry for the delay in responding but things have
> been busy around here -- no, not "sword" busy,
> unfortunately! I've yet to look through that book
> for your tsuba but will make a point to do so
> tomorrow (or later tonight). 
> 
> I'm not "married" this book but I've just recently
> purchased a Namban book (Japanese) so honestly, I
> don't need another. My book came from a Japanese
> dealer but I can look and see what I paid for it and
> let you know, in case you're interested. I'll check
> and let you know, okay?
> 
> Skipping SF this August -- (sigh) -- since I'm going
> to Japan in October. It will feel good to stay home
> for 2-1/2 months after a short (fishing) trip south
> of St. Louis next week. Will be in touch...
> 
> Ron
> 
>   ----- Original Message ----- 
>   From: Curran Campbell

> 
> 
>   Ron,
> 
>   I was not aware there was a Norisuke book. Want to
>   consider trading for the Namban tsuba book?
> 
>   Seriously, if you find anything similar, please
> send
>   me a copy of the picture.
> 
>   Curran
> 
>   --- Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:
> 
>   > Curran - 
>   > 
>   > Finally got around to looking at your tsuba's
> photo
>   > and I can see why -- the flowers -- you think
>   > Norisuke. I have a book entirely on Norisuke
> which
>   > I'll take a look at, soon. I'm in the middle of
>   > photographing stuff in prep for our stein club
>   > meeting which I'm hosting this weekend. )Yes,
> too
>   > many "interests!") Anyway, I'll have a look in
> the
>   > book. No english but photos are pretty good.
> Once
>   > owned a mumei tsuba which was probably Norisuke
>   > work; Alan Harvie ended up with it. 
>   > 
>   > Ron
>   > ----- Original Message ----- 
>   > From: Curran Campbell 
>   > To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
>   > Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 10:58 AM
>   > Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari
>   > Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke
>   > 
>   > 
>   > Alan,
>   > 
>   > The tsuba is very thick and rich shakudo. It is
>   > very
>   > heavy. The gold wire used is also very heavy
>   > guage,
>   > set extremely deep into channels. It has
> retained
>   > about 99.9% of the inlay, but there is a small
>   > spot on
>   > the mimi where I can see how deep the channels
> run
>   > and
>   > the gold wire extends all the way into it.
>   > 
>   > According to Haynes and one or two other
> sources,
>   > the
>   > Norisuke line did work in Kinko sometimes.
>   > 
>   > I am not saying with 100% certainty that this is
> a
>   > Norisuke, but there is a similar tsuba out there
>   > by
>   > Norisuke and the more that I look at other tsuba
>   > by
>   > the Norisuke family, the more I see the same
>   > design
>   > elements over and over again. Leaf shape. Flower
>   > petal
>   > engraving. Flower engraving. General
> composition.
>   > Very
>   > much like a painting, the great number of
> details
>   > evident in a soft metal heavily carved piece
> like
>   > this
>   > seem to me a signature. There is some variation,
>   > like
>   > there is a very similar 1st gen Norisuke example
>   > with
>   > near identical leaves, but the main vein of the
>   > leaf
>   > is done in a single track of gold vs the double
>   > vein I
>   > have on this leaf.
>   > I like to figure things out before I submit them
>   > to
>   > shinsa, and sometimes if I am happy enough with
> an
>   > answer and intend to keep a piece- I don't
> submit
>   > to
>   > shinsa. I'd be surprised if I actually got a
>   > 'Norisuke' call on this, but as a
>   > newbie-intermediate
>   > having something like this seem to click into
>   > place
>   > has been very satisfying. Yet I may be
> absolutely
>   > wrong! So if I can stand on someone's shoulder
> and
>   > see
>   > further into this.... I welcome the view.
>   > 
>   > If you want to take a crack at the other tsuba
>   > that
>   > has been a challenge for me, I will dig that
> photo
>   > out
>   > too and post it. This 'Norisuke' has been the
> more
>   > interesting piece and horribly difficult to
>   > photograph
>   > given the highly reflective shakudo and gold.
>   > Photography is not a strong skill for me, yet
> the
>   > devil of a good identification is also in the
>   > detail
>   > of the other one.
>   > 
>   > Curran
>   > 
>   > --- Alan Bale <abale@...> wrote:
>   > 
>   > > Is the tsuba iron or shakudo? I don't recall
>   > ever
>   > > seeing a soft metal tsuba by Norisuke.
>   > > Alan
>   > >

> Kinko
>   > > Tsuba and Norisuke
>   > > 
>   > > 
>   > > List,
>   > > 
>   > > Regarding this tsuba: (Mystery Tsuba in Curran
>   > > Folder)
>   > > 
>   > > http://tinyurl.com/lc3j2
>   > > 
>   > > Following up on the helpful lead provided by
>   > Alan
>   > > Bale, I was able to borrow a copy of "Owari to
>   > > Mikawa
>   > > no Tanko" aka. Big Blue Owari Den tsuba book.
>   > > 
>   > > Reading through it as much as possible and
>   > > consulting
>   > > other texts, I feel the tsuba is an unsigned
>   > Owari
>   > > kinko tsuba by Norisuke or someone close.
>   > > 
>   > > Anyone familiar with the Norisuke kinko work
>   > able
>   > > to
>   > > comment? Anyone able to tell me more about
>   > > Norisuke
>   > > kinko work?
>   > > 
>   > > I'd appreciate any insight or feedback.
>   > > 
>   > > Curran
>   > >
